column4: after upgrading from dapper to edgy, i'm getting anacron emails with "/usr/sbin/invoke-rc.d: 274: /sbin/runlevel: not found", I also get it from some package install scripts as well
and I do not have /sbin/runlevel, is that bad?  and what package would it be in?
upstart-compat-sysv
k, I have none of the upstart stuff installed, shoudl I uninstall sysv-rc?
do i also need upstart-logd?
you did an upgrade to edgy without switching to upstart?
guess so, i just did a dist-upgrade
that may not have been enough. It's generally better to use update-manager
been bitten twice by that, restarted/crashed X server in the middle of the update
is a fresh install an option?
heh, I haven't "fresh installed" this one since debian sarge :D
I went from sarge to dapper, then did a fresh install with edgy. Much smoother than the upgraded installation...
yeah, except for the update takes and hour and fresh install takes a day for me to be productive again
yeah, except that your upgrade wrecked things apparently
not too badly, it's still usable
though the more likely cause was me switching from gnome to xfce and uninstalling as much of the gnome stuff as I could
/sbin/runlevel is provided by either sysvinit or upstart-compat-sysv, hope that helps
I'll try switching to upstart, thanks.
please don't recommend that -- you can get a messed-up environment that way
messed up how, i hate it when I'm told that something I've been using fine for years is "bad" with wavy arms
'sudo su', 'sudo su -', 'sudo bash', 'sudo sh' all give you mixtures of environment variables from your user and your root. sudo -i is sane. See also !worksforme
thanks, that makes sense.  though I've been using su for years and the - is supposed to make a new clean env.  I would agree that just su can make with the confusion
